overview: This two-part subject will enable students to develop their knowledge and skills in prosthodontics, including the diagnosis, treatment planning, rehabilitation, and maintenance of oral function. Students will engage in a variety of learning activities across multiple topics including the biology and pathology of dental tissues, radiography and radiology, occlusion, cast metal and porcelain restorations, fixed prosthodontics, partial removable prosthodontics, complete removable prosthodontics, implant-retained prostheses and laboratory skills.
Learning activities will include seminars, pre-clinical activities and clinical patient care.

Students will engage in clinical activities in fixed, removable and implant prosthodontics with highly effective feedback from academics and specialists. Sessions are scheduled at Royal Dental Hospital of Melbourne and Melbourne Dental Clinic. The student will develop interdisciplinary links with other dental postgraduate programs to develop skills in intra- and interprofessional collaborative practice to provide comprehensive person-centred care.
intended learning outcomes: Identify and interpret the pathology associated with the loss of oral structures and its impact on health.
Apply the principles of occlusion, materials science and treatment planning to evidence based clinical practice.
Apply knowledge relating to removable, fixed and implant prosthodontics at an advanced level.
Create and develop evidence-based treatment plans for patients.
Demonstrate a high level of clinical proficiency in providing prosthodontic care to patients.

assessments.description: Practical Assessment / Pre‐Clinical assessment prior to being allowed to start patient care. 1.5 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Must be passed
Case presentation and defence of known and prepared clinical case. The emphasis is on case management to date.. 1 hours
assessments.timing: End of Year Assessment Period – Teaching Period 1
End of Year Assessment Period – Teaching Period 1

assessments.description: Topic based seminar presentation. The emphasis is on the understanding of the prepared topic.. 1 hours
assessments.timing: Second half of the Teaching Period – Teaching Period 2

assessments.description: Case presentation and defence of known and completed clinical case. 1 hours
assessments.timing: End of Year Assessment Period – Teaching Period 2
End of Year Assessment Period – teaching period 2

assessments.description: Clinical Portfolio. 15000 words (equivalent). Hurdle requirement:. Must have made satisfactory progress towards the Clinical Portfolio by the end of Part 1. Portfolio is submitted in Part 2 of the subject
assessments.timing: Throughout the teaching period for Part 1 and Part 2

assessments.description: Attendance Requirement. Hurdle requirement:. 90% Attendance for all Seminars & Clinical Sessions

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
